benchmark_details.name: Exploring Graph Tasks with Pure LLMs: A Comprehensive Benchmark and Investigation
benchmark_details.overview: This paper provides a comprehensive benchmarking framework for evaluating the performance of pure large language models (LLMs) on graph tasks, including node classification and link prediction, with a focus on instruction tuning and few-shot scenarios. It assesses the capabilities of LLMs in understanding graph structures and their robustness across various data conditions.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To benchmark pure LLMs on graph tasks and explore their performance in few-shot learning and transferability settings.

data.source: Datasets used include Cora, PubMed, OGBN-ArXiv, OGBN-Products.
data.size: Cora: 2,708 nodes, 5,429 edges; PubMed: 19,717 nodes, 44,338 edges; OGBN-ArXiv: 169,343 nodes, 1,166,243 edges; OGBN-Products: 2,449,029 nodes, 61,859,140 edges.

methods: Empirical performance evaluation over various models
methodology.calculation: Mean accuracy is calculated across different graph tasks and datasets to evaluate model performance.
methodology.interpretation: Higher accuracy indicates better performance of LLMs on graph classification and link prediction tasks.
methodology.baseline_results: Best performing models include instruction-tuned Llama8B and Qwen-plus for node classification and link prediction tasks.
methodology.validation: Models were validated through standard training/validation/test splits.
